resources.title: Our love of the cloud is making a green energy future impossible
resources.author: Mills, Mark / Tech Crunch
resources.description: Appears in Module 5 â€”Â 'An epic number of citizens are video-conferencing to work in these lockdown times. But as they trade in a gas-burning commute for digital connectivity, their personal energy use for each two hours of video is greater than the share of fuel they would have consumed on a four-mile train ride. Add to this, millions of students 'driving' to class on the internet instead of walking.'
resources.alt_resource:
• Artificial intelligence and climate change: ethical issues (Journal Article)
  • Achieving a Sustainable Future through Technology | COP26 | Accenture (Video)
  • Ponnalagarsamy, S., Geetha, V., Pushpavalli, M., & Abirami, P. (2021). Impact of IoT on Renewable Energy. In I. Singh, Z. Gao, & C. Massarelli (Eds.), IoT Applications Computing. IntechOpen. https://doi.org/10.5772/intechopen.98320 (Journal Article)
resources.apa_reference: Mills, M. (2020, April 25). Our love of the cloud is making a green energy future impossible. TechCrunch. https://tcrn.ch/3eKG2oF

resources.title: Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, and Deep Learning
resources.author: Gensler, G.
resources.description: This course material from MIT reviews artificial intelligence and machine learning. It is part of a series of courses related to FinTech (finance technology). This course demonstrates how deeply embedded artificial intelligence and machine learning are becoming in all of our systems - including financial systems.
resources.apa_reference: Gensler, G. (2020). Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, and Deep Learning. MIT OpenCourseWare.

resources.title: Algorithms of oppression: how search engines reinforce racism
resources.author: Noble, Safiya Umoja
resources.description:
Appears in MODULE 5: Algorithms.

A revealing look at how negative biases against women of color are embedded in search engine results and algorithms.
resources.alt_resource:
• Toward a Sociology of Artificial Intelligence: A Call for Research on Inequalities and Structural Change (More by this author)
  • Captivating Technology: Race, Carceral Technoscience, and Liberatory Imagination in Everyday Life (eBook}
resources.apa_reference: Noble, S.U. (2018). Algorithms of Oppression: How Search Engines Reinforce Racism. NYU Press

resources.title: Toward a Sociology of Artificial Intelligence: A Call for Research on Inequalities and Structural Change
resources.author: Joyce, Kelly; Smith-Doerr, Laurel; Alegra, Sharla; Bell, Susan; Cruz, Taylor; Hoffman, Steve G.; Noble, Safiya Umoja; Shestakofsky, Benjamin
resources.description: A review and agenda for the sociology of artificial intelligence. Asks for sociologists to 'play a leading role in the imagining and shaping of AI futures.'
resources.apa_reference: Joyce, K., Smith-Doerr, L., Alegria, S., Bell, S., Cruz, T., Hoffman, S. G., Noble, S. U., & Shestakofsky, B. (2021). Toward a Sociology of Artificial Intelligence: A Call for Research on Inequalities and Structural Change. Socius. https://doi.org/10.1177/2378023121999581

resources.title: (Not) getting paid to do what you love: gender, social media, and aspirational work
resources.author: Duffy, Brooke Erin
resources.description: Duffy asks whether the passion projects of online entrepreneurs are 'paying off'. The author interviewed prominent social media producers, finding that very few were profiting from the labour they were putting forth. The author calls for us to be more critical of techno-enthusiast optimism, beware of buzz-word headlines, and consider the framework of aspirational labour to evaluate the connections between (often) female content creators and their (under)/un-paid labour.
resources.apa_reference: Duffy, B. E. (2017). (Not) Getting Paid to Do What You Love: Gender, Social Media, and Aspirational Work. Yale University Press. http://www.jstor.org/stable/j.ctt1q31skt

resources.title: In/Visibilty in Social Media Work: The Hidden Labor Behind Brands
resources.author: Duffy, Brooke Erin; Sawey, Megan
resources.description: This article goes in-depth into interviews with 'social media professionals. The authors propose a visibility paradox: hidden behind a brand and/or social media platform of some prominence may be personal identity and labour performed to attain any media status.

resources.title: Failures of Awareness: The Case of Inattentional Blindness
resources.author: Simons, D
resources.description:
This module describes the history and status of research on inattentional blindness, discusses the reasons why we find these results to be counterintuitive, and the implications of failures of awareness for how we see and act in our world.

Cover Image Credit: Mike Licht, https://goo.gl/z7rkve, cc4 BY 2.0, https://goo.gl/v4Y0Zv
